title: Rokkk
descriptions:
Rokkk (2010) is a Hindi supernatural thriller that blends police procedural with haunted-house horror. Inspector Ranvir is assigned to investigate a grisly, unexplained death connected to a reclusive couple, Rajeev and Anushka, who have recently moved into an old colonial bungalow rumored to be cursed. Anushka appears traumatized and insists a malevolent presence in the house is targeting her, but evidence keeps circling back to her as the prime suspect in a series of eerie incidents: locked-room disturbances, apparitions, and sudden deaths that seem impossible to stage.

Ranvir, a rationalist, initially dismisses the paranormal angle and probes the couple’s past, uncovering a chain of secrets: a previous relationship marred by betrayal, a concealed tragedy involving a young woman, and a dispute over property tied to the very bungalow they inhabit. As the body count rises, Ranvir enlists a forensic specialist and a parapsychologist, hoping to separate staged scares from genuine phenomena. Anushka’s mental state deteriorates under the strain, but her fragmented flashbacks reveal a pattern of stalking shadows, a woman’s lullaby at odd hours, and a locked cellar no one admits to using.

The investigation pivots when Ranvir connects the hauntings to an unresolved death that took place years earlier within the house—suggesting a vengeful spirit is re-enacting her final moments through those who wronged her. Confronted with mounting supernatural evidence and a timeline that incriminates Rajeev as much as it exonerates Anushka, Ranvir must decide whether justice lies in handcuffs or in confronting the curse head-on.

The climax unfolds during a storm-lashed night when the truth behind the original victim’s demise is revealed. Confessions are forced by fear, the spirit claims her due, and the house exacts a final toll. In the aftermath, Ranvir files a report that acknowledges the facts but leaves room for the inexplicable, while the bungalow stands silent—its doors seemingly closed, yet waiting for the next soul brave enough to enter.
